#Text=1.
#Text=Introduction
#Text=Nowadays , the interest of having a digital model of real-life scenarios is increasing .
#Text=This model can be used to update and track the behaviour of an infrastructure through its whole life cycle .

#Text=In the railway field , with the arrival of the high-speed train and the high request for its maintenance and inspection , research concerning technical and technological improvements has increased .

#Text=One of the main concerns of the railway industry is the irregularities affecting the rail track layout , as well as the perfect state of the catenary to fulfil the requirements of gauge , among others .
#Text=These elements have a big repercussion in the security of the whole railway system .
#Text=Hence , railway companies invest their resources for the optimal inspection and maintenance of the infrastructures .
#Text=This is where laser scanning systems come into consideration .
#Text=In recent years , the applications for laser scanning technology have increased .
#Text=Until now , the main applications involving this type of data were dimensional control , 3D modelling , urban planning , and , more recently , BIM ( building information modelling ) .
#Text=The main characteristic of laser scanners is their capacity for obtaining large amounts of data with high accuracy in a short period of time .
#Text=Usually , this information was processed manually or semi-automatically .
#Text=The monotony of this task called for the necessity of automatically process the generated three dimensional ( 3D ) point clouds .
#Text=This work arises due to the lack of specific methods for classifying and inspecting railway point clouds , and especially railway power lines .
#Text=It is focused on the automatic classification of MLS point clouds of the aerial contact line system from railway tunnels , and its later inspection .
#Text=The aerial contact line is a set of overhead cables on top of the railway line .
#Text=They provide electrical supply to electric trains .
#Text=These cables are placed over the vehicle ’s superior gauge limit , being the electrical supply provided through pantographs .

#Text=The system is composed by three different categories of cables : ( i ) Contact wire , from which the pantograph takes the power for the train ; ( ii ) suspension or catenary wire , which resists and supports the catenary weight and keeps the contact wire in a constant height ; and ( iii ) droppers , which are vertical elements that help to maintain the contact wire in that constant height , and are fixed in between the suspension and the contact wire .
#Text=These three types of elements are hanged over the train ’s car with poles or cantilever arms .
#Text=The present paper is divided into the next sections :

#Text=Section 2 presents a review of the literature related with this work ; Section 3 explains the methodology , which is in charge of the classification of points conforming both the contact and the suspension wires , and the inspection of these cables ; Section 4 describes the equipment used for the data gathering ; Section 5 exposes the results obtained for the datasets on disposal ; and , lastly , the conclusions to this research together with future lines of work to be considered are exposed in Section 6 .
